body:
@shawnding, looks like you accidentally closed one of my review comments that wasn't addressed (please be more careful):

> What happens when the location URI is not set on the Database passed to Hive? Does Hive assign one itself?
> 
> If Hive assigns a location, then I think this doesn't need to check that the client's warehouse location is set.

I'd still like to find out what happens in this case.
The public constructor of `ColumnChunkPageWriteStore` was removed in 1.11.0. @rdblue, we need to add back ctor in parquet or update class loading in Iceberg? What do you think?

thanks @rdblue for reviewing !
Done with the changes, please check.

I've flagged this as well when testing the 1.11.0 release. The general consensus was (including @rdblue I believe) to leave it as is. In the end, Iceberg is calling a private constructor, which isn't really subject to maintaining backward compatibility. Otherwise, in Parquet there would be a private constructor, which isn't being used by Parquet itself, which is a bit awkward.
@Fokko, I see. So do you plan to update `ParquetWriter` in this PR?
Yes, just did :-)
LGTM +1
I did not follow this thread but wanted to mention [this](https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/26929) Spark PR as it might be relevant.

I went through the changes in this PR. Indeed, it became much cleaner. Thanks, @rdblue!

A couple of follow-up questions:
- `UnboundTransform` contains a TODO to avoid using toString/fromString for transforms. What is our desired way of doing this?
- Transforms always assume they operate on one column, which is not necessarily the case. It seems support for transforms that have multiple source columns (e.g. multidimensional clustering) will be a major breaking change. Do we want to delay that until we have an actual need?
Thanks @rdblue! I'll try addressing your comments in a few days.

@rdblue np, thanks for reviewing !

May be I'll raise a new PR with the required changes, it would be cleaner.
Should this be closed?
I could miss something but I still see duplicate logic in those classes for metadata table tests.
Sorry was out on vacation, will take a look at feedback soon.

@aokolnychyi, it isn't clear if that Spark PR is attempting to disable this for just sources that don't support it, or for all sources. I don't think there is a reason to disallow it for all sources. The problem here is just record materialization, which we can fix. The problem on that PR is that some sources don't work and should have checks to reject partitioning by nested columns. There's also a note about HiveQL syntax, but explicitly using partitions in a query is not recommended for Iceberg -- users should instead overwrite by an expression in terms of the data columns.
I've updated this PR with some recent progress. I am working on tests. In addition, there are a couple of open points to discuss.

@rdblue I know this issue appears to be closed, but I noticed that we run into this problem when trying to use the iceberg artifact published on maven with spark 2.4.4. Is there a downside to "relocating" google commons in iceberg?
@Voltir, that sounds fine to me. I don't think I saw this issue when it was open so I didn't realize there was a conflict. Would you like to open a PR to relocate Guava?
Thanks for fixing this, @manishmalhotrawork! Nice job.

Thanks for the work, @manishmalhotrawork!

@rdblue @manishmalhotrawork, what do you think about [my comment](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/666#issuecomment-565512430) above?
Looks good to me. Thanks for catching these, @jun-he!
@aokolnychyi, I agree that we can improve multi-threading. @manishmalhotrawork is right that we should do it in a follow-up.
Yes, that is absolutely independent of this PR. I've created #726 so that we don't forget.
Thanks for working on it, @manishmalhotrawork. If you do open a new PR, please remember to close this one. Up to you which one you want to do.
Looks like this conflicts with the recent update to rewrite manifests. Can you update, @aokolnychyi?
@rdblue Sure, I will open a PR shortly.

+1

Thanks for all your work on this, @edgarRd! I'm merging it.

Also, thanks to @rdsr, @shardulm94, @lxynov, and @omalley for reviewing!
thanks @rdblue, @aokolnychyi for the help to get it done :) !
HI @rdblue : Is this means implements the IN and NOT_IN predicates into `ParquetMetricsRowGroupFilter` and `ParquetDictionaryRowGroupFilter`?

@shawnding, Sorry, this was implemented in #600. I'll close this.

Thanks to @jun-he for fixing this one!
OK
@Voltir , I see the line right before your added line did the shade job. Does that not work?
@guilload Has this work progressed any further since 8 Aug 2019? I ask because we are considering tackling the integration with Hive and do not wish to duplicate efforts.
This PR is ready for a closer look.
Ah, you are right. I don't fully understand how shading / relocating works :/

@chenjunjiedada What do you make of this though:
```
jar -tf ~/Downloads/iceberg-spark-runtime-0.7.0-incubating.jar  | grep guava | head 
META-INF/maven/org.apache.avro/avro-guava-dependencies/
META-INF/maven/org.apache.avro/avro-guava-dependencies/pom.xml
META-INF/maven/org.apache.avro/avro-guava-dependencies/pom.properties
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/guava/
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/guava/pom.xml
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/guava/pom.properties
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/failureaccess/
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/failureaccess/pom.properties
META-INF/maven/com.google.guava/failureaccess/pom.xml
```
It appears guava isnt shaded (and might be the source of our issues)

Thanks! @rdblue 

Just a reminder, could you also give an update to https://iceberg.apache.org/? So that we can reference the updated spec.
I think this is duplicated to #717
Resolved conflicts 👍

I run a few basic benchmarks locally (e.g. add/read 100 manifests that are 275KB in size and contain 10000 entries).

With this PR:
```
Benchmark                                      Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
AppendManifestsBenchmark.fastAppendManifests     ss    5  2.468 ± 0.087   s/op
AppendManifestsBenchmark.mergeAppendManifests    ss    5  4.489 ± 0.103   s/op
ReadManifestsBenchmark.basicPlanFiles            ss    5  0.489 ± 0.103   s/op
```

Before this PR:
```
Benchmark                                      Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
AppendManifestsBenchmark.fastAppendManifests     ss    5  6.387 ± 1.068   s/op
AppendManifestsBenchmark.mergeAppendManifests    ss    5  8.007 ± 0.217   s/op
ReadManifestsBenchmark.basicPlanFiles            ss    5  0.496 ± 0.051   s/op
```

Right now, we still read manifests to get stats. I think we can address that in a follow-up PR. The important part is there is no performance degradation on read.
@rdblue, how did you envision future extensions when you wrote `GenericManifestFile` and what do you think makes sense in this case?
Keep in mind hive 1.2 does not allow to disable the scan this way, how we wanna deal with it?
The Iceberg test suite uncovered a regression bug: https://github.com/apache/avro/pull/752 The fix will be released in Avro 1.9.2 and 1.10.0. We're starting the release process of 1.9.2 soon.
Still working on addressing some of the comments. (we'r testing this feature at scale in tandem on our end :-) ).. Will get back on this today.

> Keep in mind hive 1.2 does not allow to disable the scan this way, how we wanna deal with it?

Hi @alexey-fin do you mean this disabling of stats collection is not part of Hive-1.2. I do see to classes [e.g org.apache.hadoop.hive.common.StatsSetupConst] in my hive-common-1.2.1 jar

@aokolnychyi, the implementation looks correct to me. My only remaining concern is our forward-compatibility guarantee that older readers will continue to be able to read tables written by future versions within the format version in metadata.

Technically, this breaks that guarantee for tables that are appended to using manifests. I think that means we should test that older readers can read tables written with this that don't have appended manifests (I think Avro will throw a runtime error if it encounters a null snapshot ID, but will allow attempting to read). We should also probably add a feature flag to turn on this breaking behavior -- that way you can opt into using manifest files without a snapshot ID, knowing that it will break older readers. What do you think?
I started a thread on the dev list to discuss breaking changes to the format and how to handle them. I proposed the feature flag approach.
@rdblue @aokolnychyi Really appreciate it if you could share your ideas about that at your most convenience
OK I close this issue
Close this issue due to the discussion in PR #719
Working on this. Will submit a PR.

The feature flag approach makes sense to me in this case. Then what about exposing a table property to enable metadata inheritance (false by default) and rewriting appended manifests if that property is false? That will complicate the logic for cleanup but it will keep the format forward-compatible by default.
@rdblue Any thoughts on this?
cc @chenjunjiedada Any thoughts on this?

@alexey-fin, I overlooked the second if condition in `HiveAlterHandler$alterTable`. Indeed, HMS seems to call `MetaStoreUtils` to update props. 

It also looks like you are correct and [HIVE-18743](https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/HIVE-18743) is not fixed in 1.2.1. Will setting `hive.stats.autogather` to false in hive.xml help in 1.2.1?
@aokolnychyi Unfortunately it seems like it's impossible to avoid the call to org.apache.hadoop.hive.metastore.Warehouse#getFileStatusesForUnpartitionedTable in hive 1.2.1
@rdblue, do we want to bring this in? There is only [one open question](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/652#discussion_r348005717) on `HadoopTableOperations`.
@omalley @rdblue @rdsr, any ideas on how to avoid scanning the table dir in HMS 1.2.1?
Yes, I just need to update it after your review. Sorry I'm taking so long getting back to it.

> Then what about exposing a table property ... and rewriting appended manifests if that property is false?

That's what I was thinking. I don't think we should add a flag that turns on or off inheritance, though. When reading, we must always add the inherited data. Otherwise we can corrupt other places in metadata. I'd prefer a specific flag to allow writing manifests without snapshot IDs. If it is allowed, then we can append manifests and otherwise we have to rewrite them.

It looks like HIVE-18743 makes it so we can't avoid this, but it looks like this is probably only listing the table root, which contains only 2 entries: the `data` and `metadata` folders. This doesn't cause a recursive listing, does it?

If that's the case, then I think we should use the change here to fix later versions and not worry about it for 1.2.1.
Sorry, that’s what I meant by enabling inheritance as well.

Guys, in hive 1.2.1 this is really bizzare, look at the function getTablePath :     return getDnsPath(new Path(getDatabasePath(db), tableName.toLowerCase()));
it IGNORES the real table location (if it is not default) and just goes to warehouse_dir/tableName
so unless you use the default warehouse location it scans nothing!

on the other hand in hive 2.3.2:
        Path tablePath = this.getDnsPath(new Path(table.getSd().getLocation()));

so this PR fixes things for hive 2.3.2, in hive 1.2.1 you cant really disable the scan but you can work
around it by providing custom location

Commits don't wait in a queue. Committers write out metadata optimistically and will retry if another process commits first. The location swap must be done to get a linear history, but we try to make the remainder of the commit a light-weight operation by caching changes are reusing them.

For example, an append will create a new manifest file. When an append retries, it doesn't rewrite the manifest file from the first commit attempt. Instead, it updates the now-current metadata by adding the same manifest from the first try. That saves time and effectively does the majority of the metadata write work in parallel.

Sorry, I thought this was waiting on the Avro change so I hadn't been looking at it.

Has anyone validated the 1.11.0 version of Parquet? I haven't heard of anyone running it in production. Because we are using reflection here, Parquet is harder to swap out with your own version because we would require code changes. That means it's riskier to publish an Iceberg release that depends on Parquet 1.11.0.

What about keeping the current reflection code and adding a new alternative so that we can work with both versions? Then people can roll back if 1.11.0 is problematic.
Thanks, @rdsr! I'll review this as soon as I can to unblock #315.

Okay, sounds like 1.2.1 is just broken, but we can at least make this change to fix other versions. Let's get this in and we can see about fixing 1.2.1 if anyone has ideas later. Thanks @alexey-fin! Nice work.
Good catch, thanks for fixing this.
@aokolnychyi Could you please review it at your most convenience?

It contains a lot of bug fixes: https://github.com/apache/parquet-mr/blob/master/CHANGES.md#bug

I've added fallback support. I've tested this by switching the statement around so that the exception is caught and the other constructor is being invoked.
Thanks for fixing this, @Fokko!

Does it make sense for `ManifestFile` to have stats like row-count, added-row-count, and deleted-row-count? I think those are the main ones that we care about that are not available because manifests already have file counts. I think it may make sense to add those to `ManifestFile`. 3 more longs aren't going to be a ton of space in the manifest list.
@rdblue , Any comment on this? Thanks in advance!
@rdblue Thanks for your review and comments! All are addressed. Would you please review it at your most convenience.
Thanks @waterlx! Looks good so I merged it.
Thanks @massdosage! Looks good to me.

@chenjunjiedada, I think I was wrong about this issue. I was referring to the note here, where we are converting Iceberg filters to Parquet filters: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetFilters.java#L207

But that code path is only used when reading Parquet files with a Parquet `ReadSupport`. We don't do that for Spark, we use [the Iceberg reader](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/Parquet.java#L231-L233) now to avoid the overhead of `ReadSupport` and to implement our own row group filters (that support, for example, Decimal and IN).

The new read path already has support for decimal because it [converts Parquet min/max stats](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetMetricsRowGroupFilter.java#L104) to the objects that Iceberg uses. That [conversion supports decimal](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetConversions.java#L71).

So the new read path that we actually use already supports decimal predicates. We could go back and fix the old read path, but I don't think that we want to spend the effort since the problem is knowing what physical type to pass to Parquet (int, long, or binary).

I think we should mark this issue completed. What do you think?
I also tested a simple query with row group skipping and it worked, that's why the confusion in [my earlier comment](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/issues/684#issuecomment-564014720).
Sorry, that was my mistake.
Thanks for your explanation.
@aokolnychyi Would you please help to close this issue as PR #736 is merged?
Hi @rdblue has this issue addressed by PR #327 ? Could you please close this issue?
I think we could close this issue. Shall we?
@rdblue Would you please help to close this issue? It seems that I can not help to close the issues that are not opened by me 8-）
@rdblue  i'v addressed all pending comments. Thanks for your patience. This PR is ready to review again.
Thanks for fixing it, @waterlx!
I think #327 provided a basis and #398 implemented `startsWith` in our dictionary and metrics filters in Parquet. @rdblue, is this what you mean by this issue?
Looks good to me.

Sorry to jump in but maybe this issue refers to handle STARTS_WITH case with an UserDefinedPredicate [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/542c0b3d49518b5105d4f9a30c65f474ea62fd97/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetFilters.java#L177).

When I opened this issue, I was thinking about the old read path. That's the one that @maqroll correctly pointed to. But we now use the new read path and the row group filters are [`ParquetMetricsRowGroupFilter`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetMetricsRowGroupFilter.java) and [`ParquetDictionaryRowGroupFilter`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/parquet/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/parquet/ParquetDictionaryRowGroupFilter.java). We needed to add support to those classes for the `startsWith` predicate added by #327, which was done by @aokolnychyi in #398.

I think the only remaining task for this (and for IN/NOT_IN) is to update the conversion from Spark filters to use the new Iceberg expressions.
I'm going to close this one since I think it covers a case that we don't really need to worry about.
Thanks all for the feedback, sorry for late response. I will address them soon.
Thanks for the review @rdblue! . I addressed your comments!

@rdblue Got your idea, thank! I am reading the code to get a full understanding of your idea.
Ready to close this issue.
@aokolnychyi are you currently working on this issue, if not I'd like to take a shot on it.
